Award.AwardTitle: International Conference on Representation Theory and Commutative Algebra
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Conference on Representation Theory and Commutative Algebra, to be held April 24-27 at the University of Connecticut, will bring researchers of all levels together to further explore the connections between the fields mentioned in the title. Broadly speaking, representation theory attempts to realize abstract algebraic objects in concrete terms, usually via collections of matrices or other well-understood constructs. The philosophy is that to better explore the behavior of a group (arising as symmetries of objects) or an algebra (arising as functions between objects) or any other pertinent algebraic structure, one can start by characterizing all manners in which such a structure can act upon a set. Writing down such a characterization can be a tremendously difficult problem, but there are fields of mathematics that can lead to deeper understanding of these actions, including commutative algebra. This conference will examine the data that can be gleaned about representation theory from this point of view. The conference will seek to disseminate recent results while inviting the next generation of junior researchers to take part in new developments. Experts will share theoretical progress and lend perspective to the questions, and early career participants will discuss their contributions through poster presentations. For more details see http://condor.depaul.edu/acarro15/ICRTCA.html

Algebro-geometric techniques have been applied to problems in representation theory since the early seventies. The geometric point of view was put to use by Kac in locating indecomposable representations of quivers, by Jerzy Weyman in constructing free resolutions of defining ideals of module varieties, by Jerzy Weyman and Harm Derksen in proving the saturation property for Littlewood-Richardson coefficients, and by Alastair King in constructing moduli spaces of representations. The aim of this conference is to address several specific questions and a number of problems that have evolved from these geometric approaches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding provided by this conference grant was used for two meetings, one an international research conference and the other a mini-symposium of six researchers working intensely on specific research topics.

The International Conference on Representation Theory and Commutative Algebras was held over the span of four days in April of 2015 at the University of Connecticut. The aim of this conference was to connect researchers in the intersecting fields mentioned in the title, many of whose paths don't have occasion to cross in a typical year. Senior researchers gave plenary talks painting a broad landscape of their research programs and techniques, while early career mathematicians gave talks on their developing research. Many of these talks were focused on the representation theory of associative algebras, which is a field of researched aimed at understanding (generally non-commutative) algebraic objects concretely. Techniques in studying these objects come from many fields, but at focus in this conference were techniques involving algebraic geometry and commutative algebra. These consist in constructing geometric spaces whose points parameterize the algebraic objects (incorporating geometric techniques), and then studying the sets of functions on these geometric spaces (incorporating commutative algebra techniques). The most important outcome of this portion of the project was the interactions made possible by the meeting of minds. Researchers with expertise in invariant theory, algebraic geometry, algebraic complexity theory, free resolutions in commutative algebra, and matrix factorizations all came together to share their knowledge and communicate new ideas. Particularly important was that a large number of graduate students and early career mathematicians were afforded the opportunity to attend the conference and share their work. This exposure is expected to have an impact on the future development of these intersecting fields.

Later, an extension of the award was requested to fund a small working group to continue discussion on two particular research fields addressed at the conference: moduli spaces and orbit closures in representation theory. Put succinctly, when studying the representations of an algebra, one techniques is to assemble some collection of them into a coherent geometric space, called a representation space. Because of their construction, many different points in the representation space can correspond to the same representation. Though one reasonable approach to parameterizing only the distinct representations would be to simply make a new geometric space in which we glue all of these points together, this tears the geometry apart. More subtle methods for making a geometric space whose points correspond to distinct representations can be carried out, and the resulting geometric object is referred to as a moduli space. One major goal of the mini-symposium was to determine how nice these moduli spaces are in the context of a large class of algebras known as biserial algebras. This portion of the meeting has resulting in a forthcoming paper. In a related vein, the working group also investigated the general behavior of orbit closures. These are constructed by looking at all the points that correspond to one particular representation, and considering the geometry of this subset of points (more accurately, its closure). Many geometric properties of these orbit closures are generally a mystery, but there are hopes to show that one desirable property, known as normality, could be proven in contexts that depend specifically on the complexity of the representations of the algebra.
